private_information: My stack from top to bottom is A, B, C, D, E where A is smallest and E is largest
left_peg.goal: Move the entire stack of disks from the left peg to the right peg following Tower of Hanoi rules.

middle_peg.goal: Move the entire stack of disks from the left peg to the right peg following Tower of Hanoi rules.

right_peg.goal: Move the entire stack of disks from the left peg to the right peg following Tower of Hanoi rules.

orchestrator.goal: Produce a single PDDL domain and problem that encodes the Tower of Hanoi instance with 5 disks and three pegs so that a FastDownward-compatible planner can solve it and reach the goal configuration.

init.ordering: A is smallest, E is largest

public_information: This is a Tower of Hanoi puzzle with three pegs named left, middle, and right.
There are 5 disks labeled A, B, C, D, E from smallest (A) to largest (E).
Only one disk can be moved at a time.
You may never place a larger disk on top of a smaller one.
Initial configuration: left peg has disks top to bottom A, B, C, D, E; middle peg empty; right peg empty.
Goal configuration: right peg has disks top to bottom A, B, C, D, E; left and middle pegs empty.

describe.system_prompt: You are an agent representing the left peg. Provide a concise and machine-readable description of your local stack and any invariant facts about your peg. Do not produce PDDL.
describe.prompt: Your name is left_peg. Use your private information to produce a machine-readable state description that lists disks from top to bottom and any constraints. Keep it compact.

describe.system_prompt: You are an agent representing the middle peg. Provide a concise and machine-readable description of your local stack and any invariant facts about your peg. Do not produce PDDL.
describe.prompt: Your name is middle_peg. Use your private information to produce a machine-readable state description that lists disks from top to bottom and any constraints. Keep it compact.

describe.system_prompt: You are an agent representing the right peg. Provide a concise and machine-readable description of your local stack and any invariant facts about your peg. Do not produce PDDL.
describe.prompt: Your name is right_peg. Use your private information to produce a machine-readable state description that lists disks from top to bottom and any constraints. Keep it compact.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent PDDL modeling and planning. Your job is to integrate local state descriptions from the agents and produce a single PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem file that encode the full Tower of Hanoi instance for use with the FastDownward planner. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep actions and predicates unambiguous and ensure the produced PDDL is compatible with FastDownward requirements.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Use the environment public information and the state descriptions from the three peg agents to produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that model the Tower of Hanoi puzzle with disks A B C D E and pegs left middle right. The domain should include predicates and actions to move a top disk from one peg to another respecting the rule that larger disks cannot be placed on smaller disks. The problem should encode the initial state with left peg holding A B C D E top-to-bottom and goal state with right peg holding A B C D E top-to-bottom. Keep agent actions distinct if you represent agents explicitly, but the main requirement is a FastDownward-ready domain and problem. Enclose the domain in <domain> tags and the problem in <problem> tags.
